caption: Hotel Particulier full of Asian art (netsuke) as it was in 1880. Free guided visit in very small groups with an excellent docent. Very difficult to get a ticket : reservations a must at least 2 months in advance.
Magical museum. Could have spend the day there. It would be great if they would offer an English tour. My French is very basic and would have loved to learn more about Clemence

Emery Museum, a very, very beautiful discovery, an incredible guided tour of a cabinet of curiosities, an hour is not much to discover this magnificent collection of objects. Everything has remained as imagined by Clémence Desgranges or Emery, plus the museum has a fabulous history to allow us to admire this collection.
A little gem that can only be visited in small groups at specific times. A speaker takes you on a journey to China and Japan for 1 hour in this sumptuous setting, discovering thousands of objects.
Reservations are required and times are limited, but recommended. It's a fun exhibit that gives you a sense of how the French enjoyed Japanese/Chinese art. The cute figures are a highlight.
What a nice surprise! Very nice collection, interesting guide. Too bad the visit is so short, done at a leisurely pace...

I loved this place where I had never been! The private mansion alone is a magical place, timeless; Clémence d’Ennery’s collections are magnificent curiosities, like the display cases inlaid with mother-of-pearl. We don't know where to look, there's so much to see. Reservations essential, and the place is worth the detour! I recommend this cabinet of curiosities composed by a woman's passion for Japanese and Chinese art of the period.

A must do if you like Asian art. A guided tour for groups of 10 people lasting almost 2 hours on a Saturday morning (reservation on the Guimet Museum website 2 months in advance). Discovery of the Cabinet of Curiosities bringing together more than 7,000 objects of Asian art, mainly Japanese and Chinese. This collection was made by Constance d'Ennery. The mansion and the entire collection were bequeathed to the State. This space has remained unchanged since the 19th century.
Interesting place. Very short visit duration (1 hour). But...it would be necessary to clean the windows which are full of dust, which hinders vision. Could the Guimet museum take care of it?

Very exciting conference visit. Thank you to the speaker who explained to us the history of the museum and to Madame Clémence d'Ennery. Lots of interesting works, I would have liked to stay much longer than the time of the visit. To visit

A luxurious mansion where the family lived - journalist, playwright, writer Adolphe Philippe d'Ennery and wife Clémence d'Ennery. The Far Eastern collection owes its existence to Clémence d'Ennery, who had a passion for the art of China and Japan. Here you will find a collection of unique masterpieces of Japanese and Chinese porcelain and netsuke art, masks, Japanese lacquer boxes and travel chests. The furniture and display cases for the collections are made in the same style, made of wood inlaid with mother-of-pearl. Within an hour, accompanied by a guide (Special thanks for the interesting, complete, informative story!) I “plunged” into the beauty and history. Another nice bonus is that this visit was free for me (with prior reservation).

a secret place, where you only enter by reservation. a wonderful collection of netsuke: approximately 2000. an old-fashioned collection, where everything is piled up. with a guide that day who was a real well of knowledge. Lots of charm for a timeless place

Museum attached to the Guimet Museum on Oriental Arts about which we don't talk much, which is a shame because it has a substantial collection.  An organization to rethink because the time of the visit is too short to appreciate all the objects available to us, in particular the numerous seals. The speaker who gives us a clear explanation of the origin of this museum makes it friendly and convincing.
Gorgeous. For lovers of Chinese and Japanese arts. Guided tour by reservation required. Photos allowed on site. Excellent speaker. Duration: 1 hour

A visit only by reservation and guided which is worth the detour. I was expecting clutter but not at all. The 3 rooms (gallery in fact) are magnificently furnished, clean and tidy. as read in the guest book, the 1 hour visit is very frustrating because it is too short. we would like to have 30 minutes to ourselves. the guide that we had was very good and valuable in stories and explanations. the history of the existence of this villa and this unique collection is incredible. a secret jewel to discover is really great.

Thank you for this free and commented visit to such a beautiful mansion; a collection that is also special, very well presented and surprising! I discovered many aspects of Asian art while immersing myself in the vibrant and artistic life of the 19th century!!

Nice museum with interesting stories and items. Professional tour guide, enthusiastic welcome. What needs to be added are information panels for the items. Highly recommended for those interested in Lady Ennery's life and her elaborate Asian collection.
Exceptional little museum. Both by the quality of the objects exhibited and by the extraordinary beauty of the place.
Very beautiful and interesting museum, too bad it's too little 1 hour on site, that's why I give 4 stars and not 5.
A museum hidden in a private mansion where everything has remained in its original 19th century state Mandatory guided tour by a moderately interesting guide. Damage
Marked as open today, but closed on site. A sign indicates that reservation is obligatory... No information on the Guimet Museum website...

Absolutely fascinating collection, masterpieces by the thousands, Netsukes of extreme finesse, which represent all facets of Japanese popular culture. This will delight all lovers of Japan and artistic crafts. The speaker is extremely competent. However, I would have liked to have had more time to contemplate the objects, and I would have liked to know more about the objects, and that the place of Mr. and Mrs. d'Ennery was less in the visit.  Please note, only by reservation, book in advance.

The museum itself is very good. If you want to visit this museum, you must make a reservation. On the other hand, these are obligatory guided tours of 1 hour. The guide spoke too much too quickly, she moved quickly from one room to another room. Visitors didn't even have time to look at the objects, sculptures or take photos. Barely 1 hour of the visit had passed, the security guard immediately took us out. I find there is no respect. Visiting a museum in 1 hour is not possible. We can't even visit this museum in peace, it's really disgusting on their part, and the 9 euros that I gave to this museum is not at all deserved. I will never set foot in the Ennery museum again. To flee. Don't waste your money and time on this Ennery museum!!!

Guided tour Saturday March 2 at 11:30 a.m. with an exciting and passionate tour guide. Thank you ma’am! Reservation via the Guimet Museum website (book in advance) with guided tour only on Saturdays for a duration of 1 hour.

Finally the opportunity to visit the Ennery museum and its fabulous collection of Chinese and Japanese art. Very good comments by the speaker. Booking the visit has become simpler, it is possible to book your conference visit directly on the online ticket office of the Guimet museum on which Ennery depends.

This museum is attached to the Guimet museum. However, despite the richness of his collection, he appears to be a poor relation. Right down to the plastic bucket to catch the rain in an exhibition room, nothing is missing in the testimony of poverty: bad lighting, bad museography. IT'S A SHAME to leave this little gem in such a state. Certainly, “culture” credits are not in good shape. But sponsorship should be able to compensate for government negligence (help Sony, Mitsu, Nikon, Toyota....)
Very interesting VG by a guide who masters her subject.
one-hour visit, reservation required
Museum with exceptional Chinese and Japanese pieces. An incredible collection of netsuke

An unknown jewel in Paris. Tribute to Madame d'Ennery for having created it and bequeathed it to the French State. And a big thank you to the speaker for showing it around with love. The only point to improve, but unfortunately it takes money..., the lighting of the exposed rooms. Revisited on July 1st with as much pleasure, another speaker, another approach, sublime for both visits. Sponsorship from EDF for window lighting would be welcome.

Very sad all this... After calling the Guimet Museum on which it depends, I confirm the total closure and the non-accessibility to the collections of the Hennery museum. The visit in the presence of a speaker on Saturday morning is no longer relevant. No date for any reopening has been given. In my humble opinion, we will no longer be able to visit this museum, if not ever, at least for several years...
An exceptional museum to absolutely discover! Quality welcome, speaker who gave us a multitude of details about the museum's collection and answered our questions!

Lots of interesting things. Reception quite cold. 0as friendly at all. The person knows his subject and made us feel uncomfortable if we didn't know it as well. She made the visit uninteresting when the subject could have been. We feel a certain obligation to make the visit.
I loved it. The speaker is quite charming and makes you want to know more about Madame d'Ennery. Original and interesting collection. I highly recommend
Surprising museum. Amazing in the presentation of the works... A little dusty but very acceptable. The multiplicity of objects tells us a lot about customs and divinities. I recommend 100%
Museum to visit, reservation required, could be a complement to the Guimet Museum. Very pleasant speaker. a real treat for those who love Asian arts.

Pitiful and lamentable, these are the only words that come to me when I notice the lack of information on this museum, it has been closed for months but no information updated at the end of April on Google and not even a poster at the entrance of the museum, which seems completely abandoned...the civil servants who manage this museum must surely be paid at home to do nothing, which should not change too much from their daily lives
Magnificent collection (of netsuke, in particular) very well presented through an exciting guided tour! A little difficult to make an appointment (exchange of emails), but it's worth it!
